senses.def: An act of ridicule or derision, or an imitation or simulation, often made for practice or display.
senses.ex: The comedian's performance was a brilliant mock of the politician's mannerisms, drawing roars of laughter.

etymology: Coined in English in the 18th century, from mock (verb) + heroic (adjective).

senses.def: Imitating the style of epic or heroic poetry, typically for satirical or comic effect by applying grand treatments to trivial subjects or vice versa.
senses.ex: The novel adopted a mock-heroic tone to poke fun at the pretensions of the upper class.

etymology: From mock (verb) + up (adverb). First attested in the early 20th century.

senses.def: A full-size model or replica of a machine, building, or other object, used for testing, demonstration, or training.
senses.ex: The engineers reviewed the mock-up of the new aircraft wing before approving the final design.

senses.def: A preliminary version or draft of a document, website, or other design, used to illustrate how it will look or function.
senses.ex: She created a simple mock-up of the homepage to show the client the proposed layout.

etymology: From Middle English 'moker', from the verb 'moke' (to mock) + '-er'. The verb 'moke' is of uncertain origin, possibly related to Middle Dutch 'mocken' (to mock).

senses.def: A person, animal, or thing that derides or imitates.
senses.ex: The comedian, a skilled mocker of societal pretenses, had the audience roaring with laughter.

etymology: From Middle English mokerie, from moker (verb) 'to mock'.

senses.def: Ridicule or contempt expressed through imitation or derision.
senses.ex: His cruel mockery of the old man's walk drew gasps from the onlookers.

senses.def: A person or thing that is the object of ridicule; a laughingstock.
senses.ex: The once-proud statue had become a mockery of its former glory, covered in graffiti.

senses.def: An imitation or copy that is absurdly or insultingly inadequate.
senses.ex: The hastily built shelter was a mockery of a home, offering little protection from the elements.

etymology: From Middle English 'mokken' (to mock), from Old French 'moquer' (to mock, deride), likely of Germanic origin.

senses.def: Showing contempt or ridicule; derisive.
senses.ex: His mocking laughter followed me down the hall.

senses.def: The act or an instance of ridicule or derision; contemptuous laughter or speech.
senses.ex: The student endured the mocking of his classmates after his presentation.

etymology: From Middle English mokkyng (present participle of mokken 'to mock') + bird, from Old English bridd.

senses.def: A North American songbird known for its ability to imitate the calls of other birds and other sounds.
senses.ex: The mockingbird perched on the fence, its song a complex medley of familiar tunes.

senses.def: Figuratively, a person who imitates or mimics others, often in a derisive way.
senses.ex: He was a mockingbird in the office, repeating every sarcastic comment made by his boss.

etymology: From Middle English mokkyng bird, from mocken ('to mimic, tease') + bird.

senses.def: A songbird, especially a North American species, known for its vocal mimicry of other birds' calls and other sounds; by extension, a person who imitates or mocks others.
senses.ex: The mockingbird perfectly reproduced the alarm call of a jay, confusing the other birds in the garden.

etymology: Short for 'modernist', originating in the 1960s with fans of modern jazz and fashion, later broadened to encompass those making alterations, especially in technology.

senses.def: A person who adopts a specific fashionable style, particularly a follower of modernism in 1960s fashion and music, or more broadly, someone who creates or adopts modifications, especially to technology like computers or video games.
senses.ex: He was a dedicated mod, customizing his scooter and adopting the era's sharp fashion sense.

etymology: From Latin 'modus' (measure, manner, mode) + suffix '-al'.

senses.def: Relating to or characteristic of the most frequent or typical case, value, or category; also, expressing necessity, possibility, permission, or obligation.
senses.ex: The analysis focused on the modal frequency of customer complaints in the last quarter.

senses.def: A word or concept expressing necessity, possibility, or obligation, or a core characteristic or element.
senses.ex: The instructor explained how 'can' functions as a modal verb in English grammar.

etymology: From Late Latin 'modalitas', from 'modalis' (modal), from 'modus' (measure, manner).

senses.def: A particular way, method, or characteristic of experiencing, expressing, or treating something, especially a system of therapy or a category of expression.
senses.ex: The clinic specialized in several therapeutic modalities, from acupuncture to cognitive behavioral therapy.

etymology: From Middle English mode, from Old French mode, from Latin modus ('measure, manner, way').

senses.def: A particular way or manner in which something is done, happens, or exists, often characterized by a specific style or behavior.
senses.ex: The therapist guided him to adopt a more positive mode of thinking about his career.

senses.def: The value that occurs most frequently in a set of data.
senses.ex: In this dataset, the mode is clearly seven, appearing far more often than any other number.

senses.def: A specific setting or condition that determines how a device or system operates.
senses.ex: The camera's night mode automatically adjusts for low-light photography.

etymology: From Italian 'modello', from Latin 'modulus' (measure, standard), diminutive of 'modus' (measure).

senses.def: A three-dimensional representation of a person or thing, typically on a smaller scale.
senses.ex: The museum displayed a detailed model of the ancient city.

senses.def: A person employed to display clothing or other merchandise.
senses.ex: The designer chose a striking model to showcase the new collection.

senses.def: A particular design or type of product.
senses.ex: This new model of car offers improved fuel efficiency.

senses.def: A person or thing regarded as an example to be imitated or emulated.
senses.ex: She was a model of patience and dedication in her work.

senses.def: To create a representation or imitation of something.
senses.ex: The architect will model the building in clay before finalizing the blueprints.

etymology: From Middle English 'modelen' (to shape, to make a model), from Old Italian 'modellare' (to shape, to model), from 'modello' (model, pattern), from Latin 'modulus' (measure, rule, pattern).

senses.def: The activity or profession of posing for artistic, photographic, or fashion purposes, or of demonstrating products.
senses.ex: She began her career in modeling at a young age.

senses.def: The creation of a representation or likeness of a subject, especially in three dimensions, or the use of computer simulations to predict outcomes.
senses.ex: The engineer's detailed modeling of the bridge's stress points ensured its structural integrity.

senses.def: To create a model or likeness of something, or to act as a model.
senses.ex: He spent the afternoon modeling a small clay figure for his art class.

etymology: From model + -er. Model from Italian 'modello', from Latin 'modulus' (measure, small measure), diminutive of 'modus' (measure).

senses.def: A person who makes a physical or digital representation of something, such as an artist, architect, engineer, or scientist.
senses.ex: The apprentice observed the experienced modeller as they shaped the miniature cityscape.

etymology: From Middle English 'model', from Old Italian 'modellare' (to shape), from Latin 'modulus' (measure, small measure).

senses.def: The activity or process of creating a representation or simulation, or of posing as a model, especially professionally.
senses.ex: Her portfolio showcased years of successful modelling for major fashion brands.

senses.def: To create a three-dimensional representation or simulation of something, or to pose as a model.
senses.ex: The engineers spent weeks modelling the aircraft's aerodynamic performance, and she was modelling the new designs at the show.

etymology: From model + maker. Model ultimately derives from Italian 'modello', from Latin 'modulus' (measure, standard).

senses.def: A person who designs and constructs physical or digital representations of objects, structures, or systems, often to scale, for various purposes such as visualization, demonstration, or entertainment.
senses.ex: The talented modelmaker spent weeks crafting the intricate miniature city for the upcoming exhibition.

etymology: Coined in the 1950s from 'modulator-demodulator'.

senses.def: A device that converts digital data into analog signals for transmission over communication channels and reconstructs analog signals into digital data.
senses.ex: Our outdated modem struggled to keep up with the demands of modern streaming services.

etymology: From Latin moderatus, past participle of moderare ‘to restrain, regulate’, from modus ‘measure’.

senses.def: Not extreme, excessive, or severe; within a reasonable or average range.
senses.ex: The weather forecast predicts moderate temperatures for the weekend, with a chance of light rain.

senses.def: To make or become less extreme, severe, or intense; to regulate.
senses.ex: The teacher had to moderate his grading to ensure fairness across all assignments.

senses.def: To preside over or conduct a discussion, debate, or event.
senses.ex: She agreed to moderate the panel discussion on renewable energy sources.

senses.def: A person who avoids extremes, especially in political or religious views.
senses.ex: The candidate appealed to the moderate voters in the swing districts.

etymology: From Latin 'moderatio' (a moderating, restraint), from 'moderatus', past participle of 'moderari' (to moderate, restrain, guide), from 'modus' (measure).

senses.def: The quality or practice of avoiding extremes, excess, or undue severity, often by exercising self-control or by reducing or lessening the intensity, severity, or amount of something.
senses.ex: The committee urged careful moderation in the proposed budget to avoid both austerity and overspending.

etymology: From Latin 'moderator', agent noun from 'moderatus', past participle of 'moderari' 'to moderate, restrain, guide'.

senses.def: A person who presides over, guides, or controls a discussion, meeting, or online group, ensuring order and fairness, or a person or thing that influences or controls the pace or intensity of a situation or process.
senses.ex: The trained moderator helped the committee reach a consensus by carefully guiding their deliberations.

senses.def: A substance or device used to control or reduce the rate or intensity of a physical or chemical process.
senses.ex: Graphite rods are used as moderators to slow down neutrons in certain types of nuclear reactors.

etymology: From Latin 'modernus' (belonging to the present time), from 'modo' (by the present time, just now).

senses.def: Relating to or characteristic of the present or recent times, as opposed to the remote past; up-to-date, advanced, or typical of current styles, methods, or thought. It can also refer to a departure from traditional forms, especially in the arts or a specific historical period following the medieval era.
senses.ex: The city’s vibrant cultural scene thrives on its blend of historic charm and strikingly modern design.
